title.narrative: Improving the sustainability performance of the Dutch textile sector

description.narrative: In 2019 Solidaridad participated in Europe in the AGT, the SAC and the SLCP (Social and Labor Convergence Project) Solidaridad took a stronger position on the implementation of voluntary agreements, by focusing on shared remediation and continuous improvement initiatives to reduce audit fatigue and stimulating individual action of brands. Solidaridad also contributed to initiatives focused on harmonization of standards and alignment of national initiatives. In 2019, 57 Dutch brands published their action plan and progress report for the AGT. With new signatories, about 50% of the Dutch clothing & textile sector now has signed the covenant. In 2019, Solidaridad has played an active role in coordinating and supporting evaluations and training sessions. In the SAC Policy Task Team, Solidaridad played an active policy influencing role through co-developing proposals to the EU Commision on building blocks for a circular economy and environmental footprint directed to the EU policy making processes. Solidaridad was elected to represent the CSO constituency in the SLCP Council. As its chosen vice chair we were active in the design of the strategic plan and engagement of new brands. In 2019, Solidaridad also joined the UNFCCC Fashion Climate charter, in which a great number of brands and NGOs are involved. The aim of the charter is to translate the Paris agreement into clear objectives and targets for fashion. Progress is being made toward more alignment òn survey and data sharing with regard to due diligence reporting frameworks. A session on alignment of the AGT, SAC and TB due diligence reporting frameworks (during the OECD conference in Paris in 2020) has been prepared in 2019.

description.narrative: Sustainable cotton is included in the Dutch iMVO Covenant, and in a specific working group for raw materials.

comment.narrative: Sustainable cotton is included in the Dutch iMVO Covenant, and in a specific working group for raw materials.

title.narrative: # + kind of policy options/proposals/recommendations submitted to pub and priv d

comment.narrative:
We contributed to the development of the resolution of the European Parliament for the EU Garment Initiative (within Policy Task team of the SAC and as part of a feedback process within the Dutch covenant).
At European level, the European Parliament has adopted a resolution asking the European Commission to table a legislative proposal that would make obligations for EU based companies to investigate abuses in the garment and textiles supply chain binding. As part of the Policy Task team of the SAC, Solidaridad has contributed to the development of this resolution and also provided direct feedback on the resolution through the steering committee of the AGT. However, both the European Commission and the European Council have not gone beyond voluntary actions on due diligence thus far. Nevertheless, by engaging in collective policy influencing with the other members of the Policy Task team of the SAC and the parties of the AGT, Solidaridad has been able to influence the Commission. Scale has proven to be of importance to make the lobby process more effective. Especially within the SAC where there are only few CSOs compared to a lot of brands, consensus on our message is needed, even though it means that the collective position is not always completely representative of ours.

title.narrative: CSOs mobilize companies to adopt sustainable policies
# of recommendations of (local) stakeholders and CSOs included in the dialogue

description.narrative: # of issues raised by Solidaridad and partners that are included in outcome of MSP dialogues / policy discussions

comment.narrative: # of issues raised by Solidaridad and partners that are included in outcome of MSP dialogues / policy discussions

Roadmap for living wage.
In the Dutch AGT, first important steps were taken in implementing the agreement. Brands that are signatory to the agreement have all made their own action plan in which they demonstrate how they will work on due diligence. By the end of 2017, 95% of them had uploaded their action plan. The first working groups started (living wage, bonded labor and raw materials) composed of different stakeholders, including brands as member of these working groups. The working group on living wage, chaired by Solidaridad, has organized a training on living wage issues for brands (attended by around 45 people). The training increased knowledge of brands on the topic and provided them with tips and tricks how to integrate the topic of living wage in their own action plan. The training was well received by the brands and the majority of them has been able to better decide on how to move forward with the issue of living wage. Brands that could not attend, asked for a repetition of the training, which is planned in 2018.
